posts.author: DarthRavadge
posts.content:
Greetings,
I recently decided to get back into nwn and I wanted to bring back one of my favorite table top characters or at least as close as I could get it within the limits of nwn.

The character was built in 3.5e, and was a shade fighter/rogue/assassin/weaponmaster and he wielded a two bladed sword.

I know he will need to be changed to get even close to what he was. For starters, I will need Hips since their is no shade race within the game. That's one level of shadowdancer at the minimum. This character is just for roleplay so it doesn't need to be min/maxed for pvp. I will be using him in single player only. I only care that he can repeatedly sneak attack from stealth and can hold his own in melee with a two bladed sword.
I look forward to hearing your suggestions!
Thank you

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Greetings DarthRavadge

To summarise:
- Two bladed sword wielding fighter / rogue / shadowdancer
- Repeated sneak attack from stealth
- Able to manfight in 1v1 combat
- Single player undisclosed module

I believe this is extremely achievable and I have some ideas to create a build for you, however I would like to know: 

- where you plan to play your character (ie is this original campaign / shadows of undrentide / hordes of the underdark, or are you going through Aielund, or another module etc...). This affects the level limit and how the build is designed. Original campaign you are probably getting to level 15-16. Hordes of the Underdark, level 28 max. Aielund about level 36-38 max. I will want to get you the 'good stuff' as soon as possible rather than waiting to later. 
- Confirm racial preference (I presume Human is ok?)

If there are any other features, like is he/she very persuasive, is he a good trader, does he/she have good lore, does he/she set and disable traps, open locks etc etc that would also assist me further but I can work without it too.

Also does your character have a name too? I am curious and would add a richness to any discussion

posts.author: DarthRavadge
posts.content:
The characters name is Doridan Regalat. He was a human assassin that became a worshiper of shar and was offered the transformation into being a shade so that he could hunt down the church's enemies more efficiently.

I was planning on playing him through multiple modules. I was going to begin in the original campaign, then through undrentide and hordes. I realize I will steam through undrentide given my character level at that point but I wanted to rack up some extra xp before hordes. I'm playing on console now so I dont have access to downloadable modules anymore.

As for skills he was rather intelligent so had plenty of points to spend. I'm willing to sacrifice in this area if need be though. I mainly just want high hide, move silently, and lore, open locks, disable device for convenience.

Thanks for taking a look

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Thanks DarthRavadge

This is what I came up with
Two-bladed sword wielding rogue with max stealth, max UMD/Tumble, max disable trap, and points in search, open lock, set trap etc etc
With 6 attacks per round (7 with haste), up to 9d6 sneak attack / hit, +6-12 damage / hit from strength (depending whether you can reach the Str cap) and +6 damage / hit from weapon specialization/epic weapon specialization, this guy will be a physical damage dealing beast.
Sneak attacks can be maximised through stealth, HiPS, improved knockdown or UMD to create summons to generate more flanking attacks
Once you get Crippling Strike your sneak attacks will destroy your opponent's strength score, stopping the from fighting effectively against you.

This guy can also disable or even retrieve traps, then set them (up to deadly traps) against your opponents.
I also maxed out persuasion, it is always nice to get maximal NPC rewards during the Bioware campaigns

His weakness are his saves, particularly the will save. This is probably going to be most likely way this character is going to die. 
There are many strategies to deal with this. 
I would use items such as clarity potions, or protection against evil scrolls to protect his mind against such issues.
Another strategy is to 'dodge' targeted spells with hide in plain sight, but this will not be effective against area of effect spells. 
Any items with mind immunity will be highly valuable. I believe there is an item called a Golden Circlet in the original campaign which may be of interest.
Items can also be equipped to boost his will save, for example, amulets of will.

I could have gone more along the Shade theme and put more points in shadowdancer (shadowdancer 4 gets shadow evade, which fits RP wise) but I opted to boost his will save and take more fighter levels for bonus feats, it is more powerful this way I believe.

He can wield his two-bladed sword effectively from level 2, before then he will be most effective with two short swords
I also envisaged him wearing medium to light armor to assist with his stealth abilities (heavy armor incurs large penalties to stealth)

The Improved Disarm feat is very nice for a two-bladed sword wielder, if you want this, then drop armor skin and ESF: Discipline and rearrange the ESF: Hide / ESF: Move Silently to bonus epic level (level 20+) rogue feats

AB boosts are always valuable in dual wielding builds. Potions of Bull's Strength, Bless and Aid will be handy to keep in your inventory. Improved disarm can also situationally boost AB up to +8, if it is fit into the build, read the details on disarm in the NWN wiki if you want to learn more how this works

Let me know what you think - if you need any other adjustments / tweaks let me know

All in all it looks like a build where the numbers look fabulous if you can manage one weakness well.
SpoilerRogue(17), Fighter(10), Shadowdancer(1), Human STR: 16 (22) CON: 14 INT: 14 01: Rogue(1): Ambidexterity, Two-Weapon Fighting 03: Fighter(2): Dodge, Weapon Focus: Two-Bladed Sword 05: Rogue(3): {Uncanny Dodge I} 07: Rogue(4) 09: Fighter(4): Knockdown, Weapon Specialization: Two-Bladed Sword 11: Rogue(6) 13: Fighter(5) 15: Rogue(9): Improved Knockdown 17: Rogue(11) 19: Fighter(7) 21: Fighter(8): Epic Weapon Focus: Two-Bladed Sword, Epic Weapon Specialization: Two-Bladed Sword 23: Rogue(14) 25: Rogue(15) 27: Fighter(10): Armor Skin, Epic Prowess Hitpoints: 266 Saving Throws (Fortitude/Will/Reflex): 15/11/19 BAB: 20 AC (naked/mundane armor/shield only): 21/30 Alignment Changes: 0 Disable Trap 31(35), Discipline 30(46), Hide 31(44), Move Silently 31(44), Open Lock 16(19), Persuade 31(30), Search 12(14), Set Trap 10(15), Spellcraft 3(5), Spot 19(18), Tumble 31(34), UMD 31(30) 02: Discipline(5), Save(10),  04: Disable Trap(2), Hide(3), Move Silently(3), Open Lock(2), Persuade(3), Tumble(3), UMD(3),  06: Discipline(3), Save(2),  08: Hide(1), Move Silently(1), Persuade(1), Tumble(1), Save(5),  10: Disable Trap(3), Hide(2), Move Silently(2), Open Lock(2), Persuade(2), Search(2), Tumble(2), UMD(3),  12: Hide(1), Move Silently(1), Persuade(1), Set Trap(1), Spot(5), Tumble(1), UMD(1),  14: Disable Trap(2), Hide(2), Move Silently(2), Persuade(2), Tumble(2), UMD(2),  16: Disable Trap(1), Hide(1), Move Silently(1), Open Lock(1), Persuade(1), Search(1), Spot(2), Tumble(1), UMD(1), Save(1),  18: Discipline(5), Save(3),  20: Disable Trap(1), Hide(3), Move Silently(3), Persuade(3), Tumble(4), UMD(4),  22: Disable Trap(4), Hide(2), Move Silently(2), Persuade(2), Tumble(2), UMD(2),  24: Discipline(3), Save(2),  26: Disable Trap(1), Hide(1), Move Silently(1), Persuade(1), Search(3), Spot(2), Tumble(1), UMD(1),  28: Disable Trap(2), Hide(2), Move Silently(2), Persuade(2), Spot(1), Tumble(2), UMD(2),

This looks really good. Thank you very much . This seems to be how I built my character back in the day, but I'd forgotten the finer points of character building over the years. I'll have to get back into it. I have a ton of interesting characters I'd love to resurect.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: The OC and SoU are both intended to start at level 1.  Those two stories are supposed to happen concurrently to two different heroes.  If you really must do all three official modules with one character, do SoU, then the OC, and then HotU.  The OC will attempt to adjust for your character level being too high, and you will end up close to where you are supposed to be.  It is still a bad idea, but at least this way will be a little bit less broken.

posts.author: DarthRavadge
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote: ↑
Mar 05, 2020

I'm aware, but as I said before I just wanted to rack up a couple extra levels for hordes of the underdark. To truly roleplay this character  I need to get him in to mid 30s for levels, and playing on xbox I dont have access to console commands.
I didn't know that the OC scaled though. That's  interesting. Thank you.

Out of curiosity how viable is a wizard/cleric for going through the bioware campaigns? I was looking through my old character sheets last night and found a mystic theurge that was I always had a ton of fun with. My only concern would be making SR checks at higher levels. Wizard would be the primary focus to keep the caster level as high as possible with cleric just added in for buffing/healing. Any idea how to split those levels so Sr could still be overcome with GSP?

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hi DarthRavadge

I think a lot of builds will be able to complete the Bioware campaigns, however one always likes to create one which is both fun and powerful in some way.
I am not aware of any wizard / cleric builds with up to 28 character levels however I believe I could design one which could easily meet your requirements.

I am hearing cleric light wizard heavy. 
Healing domain would be perfect for the cleric levels and your healing, you would be able to cast empowered cure serious with level 2 cleric spells, you will be casting the equivalent of a level 5 cleric spell at level 2. In addition, all your cure potions, cure scrolls and cure wands (if you have them) will also be empowered (empowered means 50% more effective)
The other domain that would synergise well with Wizard I believe is Animal Domain, to make your summons more powerful, it will work with your wizard spells. 
It is tempting to try to get the Cleric Heal spell with level 6 cleric spells but with such a large investment in cleric and only 28 character levels you will dilute your wizard spellpower.
What cleric buffs would you like in particular? If we can get an idea what cleric buffs you wish to cast, then we can get an idea how many cleric levels to aim for and put the rest into Wizard.

As for spell resistance, max toolset SR is 32 for a caster to be successful, spell penetration plus a 1d20 roll must be equal or greater than that value. Not all monsters will have spell resistance. Wizards and Sorcerers have the advantage SR can be lowered in non-monks with Lesser Spell Breach, Greater Spell Breach, Mord's spells.
Perhaps a realistic goal might be to aim to penetrate max toolset SR 100% of the time with Mord's which means spell penetration of 21 or greater.

I'd have to look up the cleric spell list. It's been so long since I played one that I've forgotten a lot of what they have available at particular levels.
Those do sound like good domains to go with. I like that suggestion.
In general I'm thinking as many 9th level wizard spells as I can fit in per day balanced with whatever useful cleric spells I can fit with the remaining levels.
I'd probably go with still spell and play him armored.
Sorcerer with some Paladin levels is something else I was considering.  The charisma bonus to saves would be great and would still provide some limited divine casting.
The character I'm recreating was a human spell sword/mystic theurge/true necromancer named Cydon Karr. He fought with an intelligent bastard sword of his own creation that gave him pass wall at will. My god that was an OP ability! Lmao

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
No mater what you do, you will be lucky to be able to even reach level 30 in HotU.  I don't know if you can load custom content on an XBox, but if you can, you could play the OC followed by Mines of Twin Summit to go all the way to level 40, or play SoU and HotU followed by Sands of Fate to once again reach level 40.  Or, play the Aielund Saga to go from level 1 to level 36.

If you can't load custom content on the XBox version, that is a compelling reason to get the PC version.  The sheer volume of custom content available for NWN makes it a tremendous bargain.

No custom content beyond multiplayer worlds like aerileth. That place was a joke. A rp server with typical childish character names.
Playing on pc isn't an option for me right now either. My rig had a meltdown a few months ago and it will be some time before I can afford to repair it.

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
I am guessing you started on Skaljard in Arelith. If you are game to try it again and are looking for RP, try Cordor or the Underdark as starting areas. Characters with silly names are generally weeded out by the DMs but Skal is deliberately designed as more Action, less RP.

I am not an RPer or perhaps I am RP light, but I have played lots on Arelith and quite enjoy it.

It is more challenging then the Original content.


Sent from my iPad using Tapatalk

I tried both cordor and the underdark with two different characters. Cordor was nothing but characters with names like Phil mccracken, lol. The underdark didn't have that but the few people I did encounter there wouldn't even speak with me so that's when I decided to try another area.
I'll give it another shot. I may have judged it too quickly.
It's definitely strange getting used to the additional mechanics like food and water. Not something I'm used to in nwn. I love all the additional character options though.

posts.content:
Well, also to be fair, there has been an influx of xBox folks. It takes a bit to get large scale immigration sorted effectively.
